Award.AwardTitle: Practices of Record Production and their Impact on the Administration of American Indian and Migrant Populations in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research team investigate the manner in which individuals interact with official documents to construct official versions of their identity and status in response to regulatory requirements. The research examines two groups: 1) immigrants preparing naturalization documents, and 2) indigenous individuals preparing federal tribal recognition documents. The research offers insights into the practices that constitute state power and define its boundaries; citizenship; the role of regulation in identity-formation; and the cultural production of knowledge. The research plan involves participant observation, archival research and interviews at three selected sites of official documents in California.

The research will highlight the ways that, in response to legal requirements, individuals use official documents to construct versions of their own identity that will help them secure their place in society -- a process that is especially important for those with marginalized status.

Although Native Americans and immigrants may be seen as disparate, even opposite groups (the former lived in the territory that is now the United States before the country was founded, the latter are recent arrivals), legally, these two populations have much in common.  Both Native Americans and immigrants are members of multiple nations, both are governed by the Plenary Powers doctrine of the U.S. Constitution, which gives Congress and Federal authorities considerable discretion in devising policies, and both groups have faced challenges in being able to gather the documents needed to prove their status – whether as a tribe or as legal immigrants.  Our research set out to examine these commonalities, in order to better understand the ways that that indigenous and immigrant groups obtain the records that they need to submit to U.S. authorities, as well as the particular evidentiary challenges that they face.

            Research funding allowed us to conduct ethnographic research in two Southern California settings:  among members of a Native American band that is petitioning the U.S. government for Federal Recognition as a tribe, and within a Southern California nonprofit agency that assists Spanish-speaking immigrants in applying for legal status.  We were able to shadow legal service providers, audio-record tribal council meetings, observe as immigrants and Native Americans compiled documents for their immigration or federal recognition cases, familiarize ourselves with a range of forms and documents pertinent to these cases, collect examples of these forms and documents, travel to archives from which immigrants and Native Americans retrieve records, and conduct interviews with Native Americans, immigrants, and legal services providers regarding these processes. We also did historical research, examining court opinions from earlier decades as well as earlier versions of key immigration forms.
